comments:
My basic problem is I have a Java project on sourceforge called "swapdv" which 
checks out (by default) under the root folder. All classes in this swapdv 
folder are of package "swapdv". Unfortunately Eclipse (in a project 
called "swapdv") doesn't like that and complains that these files need to be 
defined in "swapdv/swapdv". This is a big problem but a workaround suggested 
was to create an entry in the CVSROOT/modules file on sourceforge for my 
project which checks out one directory below where it actually is. The line 
added was this:
swapdv2 -d swapdv &swapdv

When using cvs under cygwin this (correctly) checks out the module "swapdv2" 
as /swapdv/swapdv, rather than to the root directory. However, after creating 
a new project in Eclipse and choosing Team->Share project I could specify a 
different module name in the wizard (I couldn't find any way to specify 
the "module" name in the CVS perspective) 

Unfortunately this caused Eclipse to create a NEW swapdv2 source tree on 
sourceforge at the same level as the "swapdv" sources. Basically it seems 
Eclipse is ignoring the modules directive and doing something nasty as a side 
effect. Consequently I'm going to have to send a few requests to sourceforge 
to help tidy up the problems cause by Eclipse on the project.

In the CVS Repositories View there is a drop down menu that toggles the view 
betwen showing folders and modules. Choose modules and you will see and be able 
to check out your module.

Not resolved as the "modules" view doesn't show anything. Please look at ALL 
the problems and why I'm going through this as there appear to be multiple 
issues here. I've posted the newsgroup article:

Thanks for the tip. Unfortunately changing the view doesn't do anything except 
show me the normal "branches, HEAD, Versions" folder hierarchy - none of which 
have any contents (although they do in the "folder" view)

So to reiterate the problems here.

In the CVSROOT/modules file I have an entry:
> swapdv2 -d swapdv &swapdv

Using cygwin with ssh cvs:
> cvs -d:ext:jotter@cvs.swapdv.sourceforge.net:/cvsroot/swapdv co swapdv
Will create a directory called "swapdv", checking out the normal sourceforge 
project
> cvs -d:ext:jotter@cvs.swapdv.sourceforge.net:/cvsroot/swapdv co swapdv2
Will create a directory called "swapdv/swapdv", as expected from the module 
definition

Using Eclipse.
* Creating a new project and Team->Sharing it with defaults to 
jotter@cvs.swapdv.sourceforge.net:/cvsroot/swapdv causes a normal checkout 
which will not compile due to the folder/project restriction in Eclipse (see 
below)
* Creating a new project and Team->Sharing and specifying a module "swapdv2" 
causes swapdv2 TO BE CREATED on the sourceforge site - something which is not 
easily undone.
* Using the view->modules view on the cvs perspective doesn't appear to work 
(doesn't show any modules)

And finally, ALL this is needed because I cannot get Eclipse to check out 
the "swapdv" project and compile it because all the folders and classes check 
out directly under the project folder, and then Eclipse complains 
that "package swapdv" is not in folder "swapdv/swapdv" - it doesn't treat the 
project name/folder as a Java folder - everything has to be one folder down.

Jonathan

"James Moody" <James_Moody@oti.com> wrote in message 
news:3CFF6B66.2000608@oti.com...
> Jonathan Trevor wrote:
> > Argh!
> > 
> > Eclipse is driving me mad.
> > 
> > After adding the new module (as an ampersand alias) to checkout one
> > directory below where it actually is in sourceforge (tested successfully
> > using cvs over ssh in cygwin "cvs -z3 blahblah co swapdv2") I've figured 
out
> > that ONLY through the "team->share project" dialog can I specify the
> > "module" I want (NOT through the CVS view annoyingly).
> 
> Did you pull down the "triangle-menu" in the Repositories view to select 
> "Show Modules"? That should let you select and check out module aliases.
> 
> james
>

When logging reports, please check the /.metadata/.log file -- sometimes we are 
unable to report errors in the UI and must write them there.

Jonathan,

Do you have the above exception in your log? If so, it is due to our improper 
parsing of invalid module deifinitions.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 19246 ***
